os_brick/initiator/connectors/nvmeof.py.message:
This is a definite issue for connect_volume which will have all sorts of problems with concurrency or any proper scale.

This is being fixed by the new connector.
Why can't you return any volume paths?  This should be populated if at all possible

Thank you for bringing this up! I have code we are testing with now that populatse this. We just have not seen any improved behavior with it, I would need to read into the code invoking it to get a better understanding. But anyway it is implemented and I just tested with this change to be sure and will commit it now.

This should be _execute

It's causing a bunch of "Could not generate host nqn: 'NVMeOFConnector' object has no attribute 'execute'" in http://publiclogs.emc.com/75/768575/9/check/DellEMC_XtremIO_FC_os-brick/9bcacf9/DellEMC_XtremIO_FC_os-brick/81/logs/screen-n-cpu.txt.gz

os_brick/tests/initiator/connectors/test.message: it's not affecting this test because you don't refer to the mocks inside the test, but the order of arguments should go bottom to top to refer to the objects mocked in the decorators (i.e., this should be 'mock_nqn, mock_uuid').

You should remove these commented-out lines.  On the other hand, it looks like the old tests were checking for some exception conditions that the current tests are not.  It would be a good idea to be sure that those really don't need to be tested any more.  The code coverage report for nvmeof.py is indicating 39% coverage; you can look at the report to see some areas that could be addressed:
https://db1b1a0d863b2be8e4df-f6d9d58f0487401586e66f66be7f6106.ssl.cf2.rackcdn.com/768575/8/check/os-brick-code-coverage/1f2a082/cover/os_brick_initiator_connectors_nvmeof_py.html

The old code had 87% coverage.  Of course, it also had at least one bug that you've fixed.  We don't have a specific coverage target for the project, but 39% is pretty low.  When you look at the report, you'll notice that some of the new functions you've added aren't covered at all.  So I think a few more tests are in order.

Thank you for this comment and the very useful pointer to the test coverage report.

For now I am adding a few simple tests of methods that were not covered yet.

We are actually planning on increasing this nvmeof connector code coverage to be as high as our driver, though we would like to ask to add all this extra extensive coverage in a follow up patch. Once the review for this connector is complete and maintainers are happy with the design and implementation, we will complete the more extensive unit test coverage hopefully within several days.

yeah, both serve separate purpose.

2. cloudkitty/common/defaults.py - this is only needed for confog generator tool so that generated config sample file will reflect the new value - https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.config/latest/cli/generator.html#modifying-defaults-from-other-namespaces

heat/db/sqlalchemy/utils.py.message:
Looks like it's broken by https://github.com/sqlalchemy/sqlalchemy/commit/7dd3381edb15e9699d24d78caa8a1021667ce92d (SQlAlchemy 1.3.23) where copy() call actually changing c in parent.constraints. The same logic works for columns L42.

Do we still need to do c.copy()? may be we just do copy.deepcopy(parent.constraints)?

I tried that and it failed the tox tests:

http://paste.openstack.org/show/802727/
I'm not 100% if we need the item copy, now that the constraints have been swallow copied; however, I've left it as-is to not change the loop but fix the immediate problem.

There is a typo in the change I pasted.

Should be 'target_table' and 'taget_table'.

OK, the correct fix seems to be providing 'target_table' argument to copy() command.

constraints = c.copy(taget_table=new_table) for c parent.constraints

labels.name: Julia Kreger
labels.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Do we have any links about it ? I quickly googled about it and I wasn't able to find anything relevant.

The tenacity project itself doesn't specify that as a reason for the fork. All it says is: "Tenacity is an Apache 2.0 licensed general-purpose retrying library, written in Python, to simplify the task of adding retry behavior to just about anything. It originates from a fork of Retrying" [0].

[0] https://github.com/jd/tenacity/

There's some discussion about it in [1]. Additionally you can see we were trying to get the retrying author's input in [2] (among other PRs) without response. Finally we tried to contact the retrying author off-line via email multiple times with no response.


The end goal here is to be able to push some changes to the "retrying library" (whichever that is tenacity or retrying) to support something like [3]. With retrying it was not possible because the author would ignore our PRs.... Hence the tenacity fork.



[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/321867/
[2] https://github.com/rholder/retrying/pull/55
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-April/092914.html

Sorry but I'm a bit reluctant to NIH projects that [people in] OpenStack push on projects [0]. AFAICT, retrying is working OK/fine I don't think we have had any major issues with that. So, if you can please point me to a major design flaw in retrying that justify the fork or the a document saying that retrying is not being actively maintained anymore as per comment on L11 I will be good with this change.

[0] Ironic still suffers from making the choice of using WSME

I still generally agree with the comments Lucas made on patchset 1. The best place for that documentation to happen and a discussion around if this is a patch we would take would be in a bug, that this patch was assigned to.

Can you please file a bug against Ironic about this, and include in there supporting documentation about why we're migrating off the old library, and preferably some information showing that other OpenStack projects are doing the same.

Thanks!
This is merged now, fyi.

yep, thanks, I saw it was closed, the final fix is https://github.com/jd/tenacity/pull/236
I guess we should update the commit message!

ironic/conductor/task_manager.py.message:

If its clashing with the retry import you could just import tenacity, @tenacity.retry
both reasons, I know I could use @tenacity.retry, but since the parameter name was a bit vague, I went for the change anyway
is there a reason to import like this? it just forcing the rename of retry->retry_lock...

there was another comment about this, I wanted to rename retry to retry_lock because I thought it was a bit vague, the fact that this import is forcing the change is a lucky coincidence :)
I can change the import and just use @tenacity.retry, but I think the rename of retry to retry_lock should stay.
Let's see also what others think

I guess if I got already two comments about this it's not a very good choice!
I'll remove the "retry_lock" change, maybe add it in a different patch, and just stick to the tenacity change.

ok, I don't really have a problem with the "retry_lock" rename, although it seems unrelated to this patch. I guess I just thought it looked weird that we had "from tenacity import retry" only in this file and one other(ironic/common/neutron.py) when there is no need.

ironic/drivers/modules/ansible/deploy.py.message: Any exceptions will be getting wrapped here, is that intensional?
oh yeah, true, I will add that, thanks!
we're not retrying based on exception here, not sure what you mean

Sorry my fault I meant to say exceptions would be ignored (not wrapped), if _wait_until_powered_off throws an exception then it wont be retried as its only retrying on result, the behaviour of the old version is that exceptions would trigger a retry.

To have the same behaviour you need to update the retry parameter to include
retry=....|tenacity.retry_if_exception_type()
Why is this required? 'retrying' did not set 'retry_on_exception'
The default behaviour for 'retrying' is to retry on exception, tenacity's default is the opposite.

README.md.message: This is not quite right. It is possible to have Keystone use TLS and none of the client services. Keystone sends its CA over the identity-service relation. Having said that, we do encourage turning on TLS for all services. So a slight rewording here.
Based on Peter's testing I need to stand down on this.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Please add:

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/696997/

to ensure that this and the associated keystone change land together.

hooks/horizon_contexts.py.message:
This change relies on an associated change in keystone; as we can't guarantee when a user will upgrade each charm, there is a risk here that you'll get a load of None values back as the keystone charm may not have been upgraded.

I'd suggest you grab the values from the relation, then only set the serv_* variables if a complete set of data has been returned.

This will deal with upgrades in a smoother way.

deployment/nova/nova-compute-container-p.message: Whitespace
bad merge?
same for here
and here
if we default to true, why not just use a boolean?
same, if we default to true, why not just use a boolean?
nit, trailing space
same, can't this just be a boolean?
if we default to true, why not just use a boolean?
same, if we default to true, why not just use a boolean?
same, if we default to true, why not just use a boolean?

same as line 810 where we already have a parameter NovaImageCacheTTL , was moved from nova::compute::libvirt to nova::compute::image_cache https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/690723 . we probably want to align the parameter names with the one we already have.

Do we really expect any users would try using ancient ext3 or ext2?

I'd agree to implement an interface in tht layer so that users can find available options more easily, but adding too much parameters would cause more problems with our future maintenance of tht.

IMO we should focus on the parameters useful in real deployments instead of implementing all available parameters.

I have to agree with you here. I know some tenants are still running legacy applications and some of them are probably running ext3, or even ext2 but you're right, we don't need to set these as the default. I'll drop this.
Is there any good reason to set the different value from the default defined in nova ? (3600)
yes that's a valid concern, when I checked I mixed it with remove_unused_original_minimum_age_seconds, where the default is 86400.
I thought the default was 86400, I'll change this.

I don't think nova supports disabling this feature.

Also, I'm afraid that the current puppet-nova doesn't handle the string "undef" in puppet as expected.
As discussed, we'll only pass the hieradata if this param is defined.
ditto. I'm not aware of any usecase where a user want to change this value, IMHO.
Good point, it might cause issues if changed, I'll drop this.
Can we remove this? I guess it came from puppet-nova.
Done

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/agent/manage.message: Should we still have this check for non-controller hosts to enforce a minimum disk size?
The worker/storage minimums are dictated by the kickstarts. I updated the unit tests to use 80 as a minimum disk size for those personalities.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/tests/agent/.message: Remove these as they no longer fail. The kickstarts enforce at least 80gb for these host types.

ok, these tests (test_create_host_filesystems_worker_too_small_fail() and test_create_host_fileystems_storage_too_small_fail() ) are expected to now pass in sysinv e.g. even with 79*1024 as the check is enforced only for controllers but will be enforced set by kickstart as noted.

2. As explained in 1, get_protocol_for_lb_object returns either TCP_PROTOCOL (a string) or LVS_PROTOCOLS (a list)
Does caller expect a list?  Maybe this is related to my other comment.

Yeah that might be confusing, I'm not really happy with this.

1. The goal of the function is to return whether a listener is TCP-based (haproxy) or UDP/SCTP-based (keepalived), the caller should except 'TCP' or ['UDP', 'SCTP']
I believe that returning TCP for HTTP/HTTPS Listeners is Ok, but I could introduce a new constant that would represent LVS-based listener ('LVS')

Perhaps I'd rename get_protocol_for_lb_object into get_backend_for_lb_object (that returns 'HAPROXY' or 'LVS')

oslo_policy/policy.py.message: +1, I think granular is one scenario where a single deprecated rule will be replaced by multiple new one. even any other scenario we can mention reason here with all new rules also.
we should take deprecated_for_removal also to mark that it is going to be removed in future.

> we should take deprecated_for_removal also to mark that it is going to be removed in future.

Isn't that implicit in the fact that this is called 'DeprecatedRule' and can only be used as part of a '(Documented)RuleDefault.deprecated_rule' value?

> In that case - would users create a new DeprecatedRule with the same name and check_str as the original, then set deprecated_for_removal?

No, I don't think that's wise. I'd expect people to set 'deprecated_rule' if they're changing the 'check_str' or 'scope_type' values or replacing the rule with an entirely new rule (or set of rules),  however, if they're simply deprecating the policy with no replacement then they should set 'deprecated_for_removal'.

yeah it can be in any case like stephen mentioned (changing default value, check_str or name). Other than name change I agree that deprecated_for_removal does not make sense but if policy name is changed (replacing with new name) ten old name is deprecated_for_removal right. Without deprecated_for_removal it can be case that I will keep both old and new rule.

If we think from old rule usage perspective then deprecated_for_removal info can be useful for users as they might be not sure that 'replacing with new rule always means old will be removed always'
In that case - would users create a new DeprecatedRule with the same name and check_str as the original, then set deprecated_for_removal?

I think it make sense on notify the rule we are replacing vs rule is going forever. I see the example of API going away like nova network and their policy could have use deprecated_for_removal at same time. 

I understand the use case now thanks for clarification.

> yeah it can be in any case like stephen mentioned (changing default value, check_str or name). Other than name change I agree that deprecated_for_removal does not make sense but if policy name is changed (replacing with new name) ten old name is deprecated_for_removal right. Without deprecated_for_removal it can be case that I will keep both old and new rule.
> 
> If we think from old rule usage perspective then deprecated_for_removal info can be useful for users as they might be not sure that 'replacing with new rule always means old will be removed always'

I agree that using deprecated_for_removal directly on RuleDefault makes sense. I think the intended use for deprecated_for_removal was to show we're removing something without a replacement. Otherwise I think it's safe to assume any deprecated policies are going to removed at the end of the deprecation period.

The deprecated_for_removal option is really a courtesy to operators so they can keep a handle on custom policies if one is going away (e.g., hey, you can clean this up now if you're overriding it in your policy file).

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Precisely speaking, this description is not correct.
In python 3, all strings are considered as unicode string, so "remove unicode" is not correct.
What you are doing is to drop "u" prefix (u'...') from unicode strings.
Could you update the summary line to more correct one?

and check it aginst host_cell.avail_pcpus

i think it woudl be better to pull out mixed out of these 3 ifss and just have 3 functions one for each of dedicated, mixed and shared/none

what do you think?

actully i was suggesting putting the check into 3 functions
then doing

try:
if instance_cell.cpu_policy == fields.CPUAllocationPolicy.DEDICATED:
    validate_instance_host_oversubscition(host_cell, instance_cell)
    validate_instance_free_pcpus_(host_cell,instance_cell)

instance_cell.cpu_policy == fields.CPUAllocationPolicy.MIXED:

    validate_instace_shared_cpus(host_cell,instance_cell)

so there woudl be some duplication but not alot.


regarding checks A and C

check A) Is the number of PCPUs in instance cell > total PCPUs on host cell
check C) Is the number of PCPUs in instance cell > free PCPUs on host cell

the free PCPUS in a cell would also always be less then the total PCPUS so if you check the  free pCPUS in a cell it does that transitivly. so the validate_instance_host_oversubscition(host_cell, instance_cell) or check A is technically duplication. of the later check even if they have differnet debug messages.

so this would jsut be

try:
if instance_cell.cpu_policy == fields.CPUAllocationPolicy.DEDICATED:
    validate_instance_free_pcpus_(host_cell,instance_cell)
elif
instance_cell.cpu_policy == fields.CPUAllocationPolicy.MIXED:
    validate_instance_free_pcpus(host_cell,instance_cell)
    validate_instace_shared_cpus(host_cell,instance_cell)
else:
    validate_instace_shared_cpus(host_cell,instance_cell)
except ValueError:
  return None

what your checking is not wrong as far as i can see but the if are just a little obscure

> then we set it back to
 > 
 > len(instance_cell.pcpuset) + cpuset_reserved
 > 
 > and check it aginst host_cell.avail_pcpus
 > 
 > 
 > 
 > we dont ever actully check the number of vcpus/shared cpus here

We do. That's the check at https://review.opendev.org/#/c/756101/1/nova/virt/hardware.py@1131

 > and we check pcpus both agsit the total pcpuset and the aviabel
 > pcpus.

See below. This is correct. The first check is against total PCPUs because we want to prevent overcommitting against yourself (a host node has 4 cores and an instance requests 6), while the second check is against free PCPUs because we want to prevent overcommitting against other instances (a host node has 4 cores and we're requesting 4, but 2 are already used by another instance). Those are different errors with different error messages, hence the different checks.

 > i think it woudl be better to pull out mixed out of these 3 ifss
 > and just have 3 functions one for each of dedicated, mixed and
 > shared/none
 > 
 > what do you think?

I don't think that's wise, as it will result in more duplication than we currently have. Just to reiterate, there are a couple of checks we want to do, depending on the policy.

For 'shared', there is a single check:

check B) Is the number of VCPUs in instance cell > total VCPUs on host cell

For 'dedicated', there are two checks:

check A) Is the number of PCPUs in instance cell > total PCPUs on host cell
check C) Is the number of PCPUs in instance cell > free PCPUs on host cell

(the second check is necessary here since VCPUs can overcommit, and we handle that elsewhere, but PCPUs can't so we must check that here)

For 'mixed', both VCPU and PCPU are present so it's naturally a combination of all three checks above:

check A) Is the number of PCPUs in instance cell > total PCPUs on host cell
check B) Is the number of VCPUs in instance cell > total VCPUs on host cell (*)
check C) Is the number of PCPUs in instance cell > free PCPUs on host cell

(*) this is what was missing, and what we're trying to fix here

Currently, the checks themselves are not duplicated. Rather, we guard entry to the individual checks based on the active policy. You're suggesting duplicating the individual checks. That's a lot more duplication and not something I think we should be doing. Maybe try doing it yourself locally to see what I mean?

> the free PCPUS in a cell would also always be less then the total
 > PCPUS so if you check the  free pCPUS in a cell it does that
 > transitivly.

Yes, you'd lose a little clarity in the error message but that is reasonable, yes. I'm personally okay with this as-is though.

 > what your checking is not wrong as far as i can see but the if are
 > just a little obscure

Perhaps, though I'm not a fan of lots of mini functions though as I find it harder to load the context. In any case, that's a much bigger rework than what is warranted for a backport. I think your concerns (based on misunderstanding the value of 'cpuset') have been addressed?
left the comment on ps1 by mistatke but they still apply
emm...this is a mistake also? we should check the shared cpu usage here when mixed dedicated and shared cpu in single numa node.
So this is the real change. The MIXED needs to be handled in both cases.

I just noticed it was exceeding 79 chars in my editor but I can change it back if it's not necessary to make the change.
Weird, I'd have thought pep8 would have picked that up. Would you be willing to pander to my OCD and not include this in this patch?

The problem with doing it this way is that it ignores vcpu_pin_set, which affects how all of this works out. See [1 - scroll down to Emulator threads policy, there's a nice table there.

To further complicate things, with Train the behaviour of cpu_shared_set has changed with Stephen's CPU resources work [2].

So I think we might need 2 sets of tests for thread policies: 1 for pre-Train (realistically only Queens/OSP13, since that's what we care for at RH), and 1 for post-Train. How to make that happen though is up in the air.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/user/flavors.html
[2] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/train/approved/cpu-resources.html#cpu-resources-upgrade

Shouldn't this be the number of CPUs in cpu_dedicated_set? So that if the policy wasn't isolate, it would foot and the emulator threads would float over the instance PCPUs, bug with policy isolate we'd need at least 1 more CPU in cpu_dedicated_set, which we don't have, and it fails.

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/commo.message: forgot in the previous review, please indent

indent

It's not just the additional config directory does not necessarily exist on the control host but we want it to read the additional images config of the target not of the control host. So rephrase to "Fetch the additional images config in case the playbook is executed remotely."
could use ansible tempfile then you don't have to worry about concurrent plays.
Should probably add task to remove temp directory after read
In some occasion, a non-root user may have no privillege to write a existing temp file under /tmp directory, set the permission here to authorize the ansible user to r/w the temp file.

This only removes the temp file on the target. When you create a temp file (line 52) it is created on the target. The fetch (line 63) copies it to Ansible control machine if the playbook is executed remotely. You should either remove the temp file on both machines or more importantly on the Ansible control machine. So I'd rewrite this task as follows:

  - name: Remove override temp file on Ansible control host
    file:
      path: "{{ additional_system_images_temp_file.path }}"
      state: absent
    delegate_to: localhost
    when: inventory_hostname != "localhost"
    become: no
Updated. Is it a necessity to deactivate the privilege escalation here?

You need to add become: no to this task because all tasks in this role are executed with escalated privilege (sudo) and the tasks in this block are executed on the ansible control host  where sudo may not work (wrong password).
Thanks for explaination, as my passwords are indentical between local and remote, haven't raise this issue previously.

nova/tests/functional/libvirt/test_numa_.message: this should be the defualt by the way but that said i do like seeing it explicit but it technically should not be needed.

Maybe I'm digging too deep here, but could we not hax fakelibvirt to validate this part of the XML, and raise the same exception real libvirt would if we pass it the invalid XML you mention in the bug report:

       <vcpupin vcpu="0" cpuset=""/>

It's just weird that our functional test is essentially asserting success (albeit without checking usage) when in real life it would be an instance in ERROR.

Just looked at this. I'd have to add XML checks to 'defineXML', since that's what's raising the error. We don'ty currently do a whole lot of error checking in the fakelibvirt driver in general and I don't think we want to add it since it's complex and would necessitate unit tests. I think the FIXME is clear enough and we resolve this in the next patch anyway.
Fair. And actually, since any error checking we add to fakelibvirt here would immediately become pointless with the next patch, it's not worth it.
Not required but makes the get_by_nodename call below make sense I guess.

tox.ini.message:
This is going to be *very* noisy for a default. Rather than doing this, could we add '{posargs}' to the end of this command. That way, you could pass this when you actually needed it.

  tox -e releasenotes -- -vvv

I wanted to note that I (now) know that this command line is _not_ what runs in our build-openstack-releasenotes CI job, so this change would be a local testing thing only (which is fine).

I do like Stephen's suggestion of making it doable via {posargs} though, if it is mega verbose, for those needing to debug.

glance_store/_drivers/cinder.py.message: Done

Sorry I forgot why we added this check in configure_add.

The reason we were raising BackendException is for stopping glance-api to start if there is only one backend is configured, as now we move this check here there is no need to raise two separate exceptions.

Also this will cause performance overhead as we are checking volume type for each create call.

I can't speak to what sort of exceptions are used, but hopefully there's a way to mitigate the performance overhead. Maybe add a "have I validated the volume type" sort of flag, so the performance hit would happen once, then update the flag to skip subsequent checks.

The key point is the check must be moved out of the service startup phase.

Agree, One way I think of is;

1. define one flag while initializing the driver and set it to false
2. In configure_add if validation is performed then set it to true
3. in add/create call
   3.1 check if flag is true the skip the validation
   3.2 if flag is false validate and set the flag to true
Done

This is good, IMHO, in that we will continue to fail until the volume type exists. When it does, we start to work, which is exactly what the operator would expect: glance says "this volume type doesn't exist in cinder", you go create it, and glance starts working. No service restarts required, unless you just typo'd the glance config or something.

Note that you could also do this from inside configure_add() but not fail if the exception is raised. That would be a hybrid between Erno's desire to have this validated at store-add time, eliminating the synchronous API call in the main path, if the volume type is already there.

However, see my point below.

Just curious, but do we even need to do this? Surely the volumes.create() call on L845 will fail with some characteristic error code indicating that the problem was an invalid volume type right? If the concern is one additional validation API call, can't we just eliminate this and make sure we log the actual problem correctly below?
_LE(
Done
We probably should raise the 'BadStoreConfiguration' here as Cinder is clearly up and responding?

No, that's the point here - we don't want to fail just because the volume type isn't created. We're checking to see if the volume_type is there, and logging (instead of raising) if it's not. The goal is not just to make glance tolerant of cinder not being running (although it should be tolerant of that too), but rather tolerant of the volume type not being created or available yet.
what's whe ClientException from cinderclient? In which cases we are expecting to see this happening? My main question, I guess, is why we should not log these?

Presumably this would be if c-api is down. We could log "couldn't validate volume type" I guess, but we can't say anything more definitive than that. I guess my preference would be to keep what Rajat has here, and not complain too loudly in the glance logs that cinder is not running. It's not a failure, we'll report the real failure later, it's just that we couldn't run the convenience validation at startup time.
Translation (_LE( here too.
s/check/check the/
Done
Done
Did you mean to raise an instance instead of a class, and presumably with a message?
Done
s/worry/worry for
Done
This should be _LW
Done

My reason for this pass is cinder isn't up yet so i didn't see much value is glance logging about it since there can be lots of reason for the same.
Also this was discussed in the last PS and Dan said it's better to leave it as it is.
Let me know if everyone thinks this needs to be logged and i will update.
Ok

Yeah, if this can only be raised when cinder is down, I wouldn't really think it was worth the log noise, especially since it's a perfectly valid scenario, given we will just handle it at runtime.

Now, if there are other things that could be raised here that are useful, it would be good to log those (maybe we could get an auth error here?) but otherwise I think this makes sense.
nit: If "types" is pluralized, this should not be.
Done
Technically, this should be "about a", but this wasn't changing this comment anyway, just moving it so not important :)
Done

bindep.txt.message:
I probably can help you here looking at your corresponding osh-images change. monasca-common is needed by both images you want to build and is already a part of monasca-api requirements.txt and global constraints, so you may just remove first line - you'll have it anyway.

monasca-api image may be considered the primary image and be built by default, though we would want to have control on either installing monasca-statsd or not. I would suggest to go a different path. Instead of having 'api' profile that installs monasca-statsd if specified, lets have 'events-api' profile that does not install monasca-statsd if specified. You'll need the following line in pydep.txt and corresponding changes on osh-images side: 
monasca-statsd [(monasca !events-api)]
Thus with following configuration monasca-api image will contain monasca-statsd with no profiles supplied, and monasca-events-api will not contain monasca-statsd with 'event-api' profile supplied.

my bad. should not start reviewing before 6pm 😊
i did not notice it's images built from 2 different projects, so you can ignore the second part of my previous comment.
All you need here is to remove 1st line and move the second one to pydep.txt
